I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 

 
1. 
to the Socialist Republic of Viet Nam for the Project Preparation and Start-Up Support Facility.1 
 
2. 
The  facility  will  enable  the  Government  of  Viet  Nam  to  better  prepare,  start  up,  and 
implement projects, which will improve the effectiveness of projects in Viet Nam financed by the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB). 
 

II. 

THE PROJECT 

Rationale 

 
A. 
 
3. 
Trends  in  Viet  Nam’s  official  development  assistance  portfolio.  Viet  Nam’s  rapid 
economic  growth  has  been  impressive  between  1990  and  2010.  Official  development 
assistance  (ODA)  has  played  an  important  role  in  catalyzing  investments,  as  reflected  in  the 
government’s Socioeconomic Development Plan, 2011–2015, which states development targets 
and  highlights  the  importance  of  ODA  and  anticipated  increases  in  the  number,  size,  and 
complexity  of  investments.  From  2006 to  2010,  signed  ODA for  Viet  Nam  was  $20.26  billion.2 
This figure is expected to reach $32.00 billion in 2011–2015. 
 
4. 
Aid  effectiveness  has  not  kept  pace  with  investment  growth.  Undisbursed  ODA  is  over 
$6 billion and expected to increase to over $10 billion by the end of 2015. As aid is channeled 
through  ODA-funded  programs  and  projects,  effectiveness  is  measured  in  terms  of  how  well 
programs  and  projects  are  implemented,  the  time  required  for  completion,  and  impacts  on 
beneficiaries.  Viet  Nam’s  track  record  has  been  mixed.  In  general,  ADB  and  development 
partners’  project  evaluation  reports  show  projects  completed  satisfactorily.  The  same  reports 
indicate  poor  project  performance  during  implementation  caused  by,  among  other  problems, 
delayed project preparation and start-up. Delays cause unnecessary implementation difficulties, 
increase  transactional  costs  and  postpone  development  benefits  to  the  project  beneficiaries, 
reducing  aid  effectiveness  and  investment  efficiency.  ADB’s  country  assistance  program 
evaluation  (CAPE),3 for  the  period  2001-2008,  directly  fed  into  the  preparation  of  the  country 
partnership  strategy  (CPS)  2012–2015. 4  The  CAPE  study  highlighted  “improving  portfolio 
performance”,  as  one  of  the  major  issue  for  future  assistance.  Also,  ADB’s  Sector  Assistance 
Evaluation Programs5 highlight the need for additional resources to improve the project design 
and fast track project implementation. ADB’s Viet Nam country portfolio review found that 12–18 
months on average separate fact-finding from loan effectiveness, with an additional 2 years for 
project  start-up  and  the  first  contract  award,  and  that  loan  extensions  add  another  2  years.6 
Comparisons across development partners show portfolio performance indicators for Viet Nam 
to be worse than those of comparable countries in Asia.

Development  partners  and  the  government  realize  the  importance  of  addressing 
5. 
implementation bottlenecks, including improving the effective utilization of ODA for projects. The 
ODA  Inter-Ministerial  Task  Force,  established  in  2004,  conducts  annual  reviews  of  ODA 
utilization in coordination  with  development  partners  including  ADB  and  produces  action  plans 
to  improve  ODA  and  its  use.  Decree  131/2006/ND-CP  on  delegated  management  of  ODA-
funded  projects,  currently  undergoing  revision,  is  intended  to  improve  the  utilization  of  ODA 
resources  and  define  the  responsibilities  of  stakeholders  in  Viet  Nam.  The  Aid  Effectiveness 
Forum brings together government agencies and development partners for dialogue on various 
impact  assessment,  and 
impact  assessment,  environmental 
themes,  such  as  social 
procurement,  to  narrow  gaps  between  government  procedures  and  international  practices. 
However,  these  initiatives  need  supplemental  concrete  actions  to  address  implementation 
delays  arising  from  inadequate  project  preparation  and  project  readiness,  the  lack  of  effective 
mechanisms  to  fast-track  project  start-up,  and  the  limited  capacity  of  counterpart  staff  to 
administer  projects  and  manage  implementation.  This  analysis  is  consistent  with  various 
portfolio performance reviews on Viet Nam (footnote 3), which have identified several underlying 
technical, institutional, and financial constraints that hinder smooth project preparation, start-up, 
and implementation. 
 
6. 
Project start-up. After loan negotiations are concluded and loan documents are signed, 
most  project  management  units  are  reluctant  to  do  so  much  as  invite  expressions  of  interest 
from  consultants  until  the  loan  is  declared  effective,  even  where  advance  action7 has  been 
approved.8 In Viet Nam, the legal structure usually restricts any agency implementing an ODA-
funded project from spending counterpart funds until the loan is declared effective. On average, 
it takes 8 months to advance from loan signing to loan effectiveness, over 12 months to recruit 
consultants,  and  18  months  to  get  from  loan  effectiveness  to  the  first  disbursement.  Start-up 
delays can delay projects for 2–3 years. While the revision of Decree 131/2006/ND-CP will allow 
advance action, the funding needed for advance action may still not be available.9  
 
Capacity  issues.  Capacity  to  implement  projects  varies  at  in  the  central  government 
7. 
and  in  the  provinces.  In  many  cases,  the  executing  and  implementing  agencies  do  not  have 
enough  experience  to  implement  ODA-funded  projects  well.  Even  those  with  experience  may 
lack capacity because of limited financial resources, technical skills, and ability to communicate 
with development partners. 
 
8. 
The government needs a facility that will adequately address the technical, institutional, 
and  financial  barriers  to  the  timely  start-up  of  ODA-funded  projects.  The  facility  will  allow 
selected  agencies  to  effectively  prepare  and  implement  ADB-financed  projects,  ensuring 
effective aid utilization. As this can be achieved only if adequate resources are frontloaded, the 
facility  proposes  to  enable  (i)  better  preparation  of  investment  projects  by  providing  funds  for  
preparing  feasibility  studies,  detailed  engineering  designs,  and  bidding  documents;  (ii)  quick 
project  start-up;  (iii)  the  resolution  of  project  implementation  bottlenecks  caused  by  most 
executing  and  implementing  agencies’  lack  of  capacity  on  safeguards  (conducting  baseline 
surveys, updating resettlement plans and compensation plans, and incorporating environmental 
management plans into the bidding documents), procurement (selecting the first consulting firm 
for  detailed  design  and  supervision),  and  disbursement  (opening  imprest  accounts  and

 managing withdrawal applications); and (iv) the provision of transaction advisory services. The 
facility  will  improve  project  performance,  enhance  the  quality  of  investments,  speed  up 
disbursement, and ensure the timely realization of economic benefits. 
 
A  project  design  advance  to  a  borrowing  country  from  the  Project  Design  Facility 
9. 
supports project formulation, encompassing detailed engineering design, feasibility studies, due 
diligence,  and safeguard  and  pre-implementation  work  including  advance procurement  actions 
of up to $5 million.10  However, the government has no mechanism to fast-track the processing 
of a project design advance rather than as a loan. The facility intends to go beyond the Project 
Design Facility by mobilizing funding after simple one-off approval from the Ministry of Planning 
and  Investment  (MPI),  the  executing  agency,  with  no  funding  restriction,  and  by  building 
capacity  in  the  MPI  to  implement  the  facility  and  in  implementing  agencies  for  project 
preparation  and  advance  action,  including  recruiting  consultants  and  preparing  detailed 
engineering design and bidding documents. 
 
10. 
By financing detailed engineering designs and bidding and other project documents, the 
facility  will  accelerate  and  complete  project  preparation  beyond  what  a  typical  project 
preparatory technical assistance grant can accomplish. Indeed, the facility can be an alternative 
to  a  project  preparatory  technical  assistance,  financing  all  project  preparation  from  feasibility 
study to bidding documents. The facility is included in ADB’s CPS, 2012–2015. 
 
11. 
Lessons  from  previous  experience.  In  2010,  the  World  Bank  developed  the  Project 
Preparation  Technical  Assistance  Facility  (PPTAF).  The  PPTAF  supports  World  Bank-funded 
projects  by  preparing  feasibility  studies,  detailed  designs,  and  bidding  documents  and  by 
providing resources to speed up project preparation. Several issues were encountered early in 
its  implementation,  mostly  delays  caused  by  the  complicated  application  process  and  lack  of 
capacity  in  implementing  agencies  to  prepare  and  process  applications.  ADB  is  coordinating 
with the World Bank on the processing of the facility. Findings from the World Bank’s experience 
have  been  incorporated  into  the  design  of  the  facility,  which  will  (i)  provide  a  common  project 
coordination  unit  (PCU)  at  the  MPI  for  the  facility  and  the  PPTAF;  (ii)  recruit  individual 
consultants rather than a firm for capacity development; (iii) simplify the application form and the 
approval process from 3 steps to 1-step approval by the MPI; and (iv) identify projects early, at 
CPS or during the country programming missions, for possible financing under the facility. 
 
B. 
 
The impact of the facility will be improved aid effectiveness in Viet Nam. Its outcome will 
12. 
be  strengthened  capacity  in  the  government  to  fast-track  the  preparation,  start-up,  and 
implementation of ADB-financed projects in Viet Nam. 
 
C. 
 
13. 
Output  1:  Production  of  high-quality  project  documents  and  actions  to  fast-track 
project start-up. The facility will finance the preparation, start-up, and implementation activities 
of the government’s proposed investment projects (subprojects), including (i) the preparation of 
quality  project  documents,  including  feasibility  studies,  detailed  engineering  designs,  and 
bidding  documents;  (ii)  activities  to  facilitate  advance  contracting;  and  (iii)  other  activities  to 
enable quick subproject start-up.

 Implementation Arrangements 

E. 
 
18. 
As  the  multisector  coordinating  agency  for  ODA-funded  projects  and  the  executing 
agency  for  the  facility,  the  MPI  will  be  responsible  for  executing  the  facility.  A  PCU  will  be 
established under MPI to undertake day-to-day activities. Selected line ministries and provincial 
and city peoples’ committees eligible under Decree 131/2006 will be the implementing agencies 
for subprojects. 
 
International and national consultants specializing in project management will assist the 
19. 
PCU  in  (i)  processing  subproject  proposals  and  applications,  (ii)  ensuring  quality  control,  (iii) 
developing  capacity  in  the  MPI  and  the  implementing  agencies;  and  (iv)  providing  other 
administrative  support  as  required  by  the  MPI.  The  facility  will  finance  PCU  costs  for  annual 
independent  audits,  office  equipment,  and  workshops  and  site  visits  while  preparing  or 
implementing subprojects. ADB will meet at least quarterly with the World Bank and the MPI to 
coordinate, review issues, and improve the implementation of the facility. 
 
International and national individual consultants will be recruited to build the capacity of 
20. 
the MPI and implementing agencies to prepare and appraise public investments. Audit will be by 
a firm selected either by consultant qualification selection or least cost. Consultants required to 
assist implementing agencies in preparing subprojects will be recruited as firms, individuals, or a 
combination of both. Quality- and cost-based selection at a ratio of 80:20 will be the preferred 
method  for  selecting  firms.  Depending  on  the  scope,  nature,  and  value  of  a  particular 
assignment,  implementing  agencies  may,  with  ADB's  prior  approval,  adopt  other  selection 
methods outlined in ADB's Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time 
to time), based on consultant qualification, fixed budget, least cost, or quality. 
 
21. 
To  be  eligible  for  financing  under  the  facility,  a  subproject  must  be  (i)  included  in  the 
project pipeline of the CPS or country operations business plan; (ii) a high government priority; 
or (iii) agreed upon by the MPI and ADB during the country programming mission, the country 
programming  confirmation  mission,  or  the  country  portfolio  review  mission.  The  implementing 
agency  proposing  a  subproject  will  work  closely  with  the  team  processing  it  (the  subproject 
team)  to  determine  its  outputs,  activities,  and  budget.  The  time  for  completing  subproject 
preparation will be limited to 3 years. Justification and approval from the MPI will be required for 
any time extension to complete subproject tasks financed under the facility. 
 
22. 
The  implementing  agencies  will  implement  subprojects  through  project  implementation 
units  (PIUs).  Each  PIU  will  be  responsible  for  the  (i)  timely  submission  of  the  subproject 
proposal  and  application  to  the  PCU  for  financing  under  the  facility;  (ii)  procurement  of 
consulting  services  for  the  subproject  preparation  and  implementation,  including  consultant 
contract  management;  and  (iii)  processing  of  subsequent  investment  loan  for  the  subproject. 
Each  PIU  will  liaise  with  the  PCU  under  the  MPI  and  with  the  subproject  team  to  finalize 
subproject  preparation  and  advance  action.  The  PIU  will  ensure  that  deliverables  financed 
under  the  facility  conform  with  government  and  ADB  policies  and  guidelines,  including 
anticorruption  measures,  safeguards,  gender,  procurement,  consulting  services,  and 
disbursement. 
 
23. 
ADB  will  work  closely  with  the  MPI  and  the  implementing  agencies  to  implement  the 
facility. The ADB team, responsible for implementation of the facility (facility team), will support 
and supervise the MPI’s execution of the facility by (i) exercising no objection to all consultant 
recruitment  and  procurement  managed  by  the  MPI,  (ii)  ensuring  that  implementation  complies 
with fiduciary requirements, and (iii) monitoring and evaluating the portfolio of subprojects. 

5 

 

 6 

 

 
24. 
The subproject team will collaborate with the implementing agencies and guide the PIUs 
in preparing subproject proposals and applications and assess the capacity of the implementing 
agencies  for  financial  management,  procurement,  and  safeguard  compliance.  Detailed  project 
implementation  arrangements  are  included  in  the  project  administration  manual  (PAM).11 The 
approval process for subproject financing under the facility is summarized as follows. Based on 
selection criteria, the implementing agency will discuss the objectives, scope, and budget of the 
proposed subproject with ADB and the MPI to assess the need for facility financing. Thereafter, 
the implementing agency will prepare and submit to the MPI a funding application. The PCU will 
review  the  application  and  determine  its  eligibility  within  28  calendar  days  after  receipt.  The 
PCU will then submit a request to ADB to commit financing from the facility. The facility team will 
review  the  application  and  consult  with  the  subproject  team  on  subproject  scope  and 
implementation. Upon receiving ADB’s no objection, the standing vice minister or the minister of 
the  MPI  will  approve  the  subproject.  The  PCU  will  issue  notice  for  the  implementing  agency’s 
PIU  to  proceed  with  implementing  the  subproject.  The  government  has  been  informed  that 
ADB’s  approval  of  subproject  financing  under  the facility  does  not  commit  ADB  to finance  the 
ensuing subproject.

 III. 

DUE DILIGENCE 

Technical 

Economic and Financial 

 
A. 
 
ADB will work closely with the MPI and the implementing agencies. The facility team will 
25. 
support  and  supervise  the  MPI’s  execution  of  the  facility  by  (i)  approving  all  consulting  and 
procurement activities managed by the MPI, (ii) ensuring that implementation complies with the 
fiduciary requirements, and (iii) monitoring and evaluating the portfolio of subprojects. 
 
26. 
By fast-tracking the preparation, start-up, and implementation of subprojects, the facility 
will greatly contribute to (i) bridging the gap between the end of the project preparation and loan 
effectiveness,  which  routinely  takes  up  to  2  years;  (ii)  promoting  advance  action;  (iii) 
accelerating  detailed  engineering  designs  and  the  preparation  of  bidding  documents;  (iv) 
building capacity in stakeholders to process and implement ODA-funded projects in general and 
ADB-financed  projects  in particular;  and (v) financing transaction advisory  services. The  result 
will be (i) earlier benefit delivery; (ii) reduced transaction costs as contracts will not substantially 
lag behind loan approval and effectiveness; and (iii) potentially improved subproject quality, as 
investment  loans  will  be  well  designed  with  sound  technical  information,  greater  safeguard 
compliance, and more precise cost estimates firmed up during the detailed engineering design. 
 
B. 
 
27. 
Economic and financial benefits generated by the facility will be significant but difficult to 
estimate  accurately.  The  facility  will  finance  the  preparation  of  subprojects  that  are  subject  to 
assessment  for  economic  and  financial  viability,  facilitating  early  implementation  and  prompt 
disbursement.  Subproject  investment  financing  plans  will  be  processed  in  parallel  with  project 
preparation  rather  than  upon  its  completion.  This  will  shorten  the  lag  between  the  approval  of 
the investment financing plan and substantial disbursement for works and/or goods by up to  2 
years, based on experience across the present portfolio. 
 
28. 
The  facility  will  reduce  foregone  economic  and  social  benefits  by  bringing  subproject 
benefits  to  beneficiaries  earlier.  Implementing  agencies  to  be  strengthened  during  project 
preparation  will  benefit  from  better  designs  and  higher  returns  in  terms  of  net  present  value. 
Subprojects funded through ordinary capital resources loans will benefit from lower commitment 
charges  and  potentially  shorter  implementation periods,  both  of  which  will  substantially  reduce 
total  subproject  costs.  In  addition,  the  enhanced  capacity  of  government  agencies  to  prepare 
subprojects will facilitate better project design with higher economic rates of return. 
 
C. 
 
ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) was explained to and discussed 
29. 
with  the  government  and  the  MPI.  The  specific  policy  requirements  and  supplementary 
measures are described in the PAM (footnote 9). 
 
The government  is  taking  concrete  steps  to  battle  corruption  and  has recently  adopted 
30. 
several  legal  reforms,  including  introducing  the  Anti-Corruption  Law. 12  The  government 
inspectorate  has  disclosed  the  results  of  investigations  against  corruption,  and  a  legal 
framework has been established to protect and reward people who speak out against corruption. 
 

Governance

Safeguards 

Poverty and Social 

The  financial  management  assessment  and  the  procurement  capacity  assessment 
31. 
review  demonstrated  that  the  PCU’s  implementation  of  the  World  Bank’s  PPTAF  for  over  2 
years has made the MPI better able to manage the facility. 
 
D. 
 
32. 
The  facility  is  not  expected  to  have  any  impacts  on  gender  or  social  dimensions. 
However,  subprojects  may  generate  such  impacts.  Gender,  labor,  HIV/AIDS,  and  other  social 
risks  related  to  a  subproject  will  be  assessed  by  the  subproject  team  processing  each 
subproject. 
 
E. 
 
33. 
As  the  facility  will  focus  on  preparing  subprojects  and  building  the  capacity  of 
stakeholders,  it  is  not  expected  to  have  any  direct  adverse  social  and environmental  impacts. 
The  facility  is  category  C  for  environment,  involuntary  resettlement,  and  indigenous  people.  It 
will  ensure  the  development  of  environmentally  and  socially  viable  subprojects,  which  will 
accord  with  ADB’s  Safeguard  Policy  Statement  (2009)  and  applicable  government  laws  and 
regulations. 
 
F. 
 
34. 
The dedicated PCU under the MPI has experience preparing projects and implementing 
the World Bank’s PPTAF for 2 years. The PCU still requires a financial management specialist 
to support  various  aspects  of financial  management,  assist  in providing financial  management 
support  to  implementing  agencies  and  PIUs,  manage  the  facility  imprest  account,  prepare 
periodic  financial  reports  and  annual  financial  statements,  and  arrange  for  annual  audits.  The 
PCU  will  not  be  responsible for  authorizing  or  verifying  the  transactions  of  subprojects  carried 
out  by  implementing  agencies.  The  implementing  agencies  will,  through  the  PIUs,  be  fully 
responsible and accountable for the financial management of their subprojects, except for audit, 
which the PCU will undertake. Integrated benefits and impacts are expected to outweigh costs.
